data.value: implements a method for robust linear regression.  It computes the slope as the median of all slopes between paired values.
follows . The intercept is not defined in , and here it is defined as
, which is given in . Other definitions of the intercept exist in the literature such as
in . The approach to compute the intercept can be determined by the parameter
. A confidence interval for the intercept is not given as this question is not addressed in .
For compatibility with older versions of SciPy, the return value acts like a
, so one can continue to write:
slope, intercept, low_slope, high_slope = theilslopes(y, x)
Confidence degree between 0 and 1. Default is 95% confidence. Note that
is symmetric around 0.5, i.e. both 0.1 and 0.9 are interpreted as "find the 90% confidence interval".
Method to be used for computing estimate for intercept. Following methods are supported,
'joint': Uses np.median(y - slope * x) as intercept.
The return value is an object with the following attributes:
Computes the Theil-Sen estimator for a set of points (x, y).
Compute the slope, intercept and 90% confidence interval.  For comparison, also compute the least-squares fit with

Plot the results. The Theil-Sen regression line is shown in red, with the dashed red lines illustrating the confidence interval of the slope (note that the dashed red lines are not the confidence interval of the regression as the confidence interval of the intercept is not included). The green line shows the least-squares fit for comparison.
a similar technique using repeated medians
